title: Hippocrene
text:
In <a href="Greek%20mythology">Greek mythology</a>, Hippocrene () was a <a href="Spring%20%28hydrology%29">spring</a> on <a href="Mount%20Helicon">Mt. Helicon</a>. It was sacred to the <a href="Muses">Muses</a> and formed by the hooves of <a href="Pegasus">Pegasus</a>. Its name literally translates as "Horse's Fountain" and the water was supposed to bring forth poetic inspiration when imbibed.
Sources.
<a href="Hesiod">Hesiod</a> refers to the horse's well on Helicon in his "<a href="Theogony">Theogony</a>".
And after they have washed their tender skin in Permessus or Hippocrene or holy Olmeidus, they perform choral dances on highest Helicon, beautiful, lovely ones, and move nimbly with their feet.
<a href="John%20Keats">John Keats</a> refers to Hippocrene in his poem "<a href="Ode%20to%20a%20Nightingale">Ode to a Nightingale</a>".
O for a beaker full of the warm South
Full of the true, the blushful "Hippocrene",
With beaded bubbles winking at the brim,
And purple-stained mouth;
That I might drink, and leave the world unseen,
And with thee fade away into the forest dim:
<a href="Henry%20Wadsworth%20Longfellow">Henry Wadsworth Longfellow</a> mentions the fountain in his poem "Goblet of Life":
No purple flowers,—no garlands green,
Conceal the goblet's shade or sheen,
Nor maddening draughts of Hippocrene,
Like gleams of sunshine, flash between
Thick leaves of mistletoe.
<a href="Petrarch">Petrarch</a> refers to the fountain of Helicon in his epic poem "<a href="Africa%20%28Petrarch%29">Africa</a>"
Sisters who are
my sweet care, if I sing to you of wonders, I pray that it be granted to me to drink again at
the fountain of Helicon. 
In popular culture.
The creation of the Hippocrene by Pegasus was a <a href="Jeopardy%21">Jeopardy!</a> question in September 2021.
